text: [Music] stanford university the guest speaker
for today is bill crowl we'll be discussing network and information security reflecting on the past with
bill's wealth of experiences ranging from the nsa to the private sector and then also the look ahead in terms of
future implications on network and information security so bill crowl has had a very long and illustrious career
in the security realm he was former deputy director of the nsa appointed by president clinton and held in this role
of deputy director of the highest ranking position for a civilian in the agency he also served on a number of
different government roles in terms of the president's export council he was also on the senior advisory group as its
chairman for the dni the director of national intelligence for the u.s as well as on the science and technology
advisory board for dhs department of homeland security his background in the private sector rivals that within the
public sector so he was former ceo and president of sailing corporation which was a public company prior to its
acquisition by safenet he was also chairman and board director of a number of companies that got acquired whether
it was by hp cisco boeing and has invested in a number of cyber security companies so bill for today's session
want to touch upon some highlights from your background and various uh national security projects that you've worked on
as well as then some topics related to current security issues that we face and
some of the key attack vectors uh that are important and then finally some other global implications and journal
topics in terms of security with iot global implications implications of quantum computing on security and just a
few other topics that students have expressed interest in covering so thanks for taking the time and we'll go ahead
and get started so during your time at the nsa around 1943 until 1980 there was
a project called the verona project at nsa and for the class that was a counterintelligence program designed to
decrypt messages transmitted by the intelligence agencies of the soviet union such as kgb gru can you share with
the class what your role was in that project and just provide as much as you can of a brief overview of some of the
challenges that were faced in developing that program i'd be happy to bernstein
and first i'll start by saying i wasn't there at 1943. so you have to understand
that i came into the game much later that project was started in 1943 during
world war ii it was a very controversial project and therefore it became a what's called a
green door project no one could get in unless they were specifically cleared for it it was jointly done with the fbi
uh nsa and it was directed against uh soviet intelligence it's a success story
beyond belief and i had three things that i managed to
do as a part of that program i came into it in the mid 70s it had been in exist i
actually in 1973 it had been in existence in 43 in 1948 it produced its
first decrypt of kgb communications
and that decrypt i actually remember it quite well the words start out that antenna's wife antenna was a cover name
for a soviet agent and tennis wife ethel aged 32 has two sons
helps her husband in his work and has been quite effective in
dealing with our mission meaning the soviet mission that was julius and rosenberg
that's who the message was about and of course the famous rosenberg case was decided by information that came from
that message all in all 200 agents were identified by
the time i came into the program about 60 of them had either been neutralized in terms of they left the united states
they went back to the soviet union or or they went elsewhere in the world one of them went to the uk and was a
professor at cambridge my job my second job besides supervising the project when
i came on board was to determine just how long this should run i mean how many years were we going to
actually try and break messages that only dated from 1943 to 1948
and i made a determination that it would continue until about 1980 when all of
the agents that were identified would been would have been too old or
too displaced from the soviet mission that they wouldn't be worthy targets for u.s
counterintelligence and the third part that i played was that i convinced the
director well actually the director cia and senator daniel moynihan
that we should honor the people who worked on that project for more than 30 years and so we had a ceremony at cia in which
we unveiled to the american public that the project had been successful if you go on
the nsa.gov website you
you search by name you will find a speech that i gave in the cia headquarters to the public and to the
40 or so people who had worked on the project that were still alive and you can find out a lot of facts
about the project thanks for sharing that bill so you weren't at that essay in 1943 but you
were there when you're director of deputy director of operations from 1991 to 1994 and one of the projects you were
in charge of was running its core signals intelligence missions i know this was one of the five groups that was
under director john mcconnell based on the structure of the organization at the time could you discuss with the class
the field of signals intelligence and why it was an important area yeah
signals intelligence is the intercept of radio communications in that date
because the internet wasn't really in existence yet was a couple more years three more years before it
came into existence but it's the intercept of radio communications of foreign nations in order to produce
intelligence and it included military intelligence that is
information that was very critical during wartime the communications of military forces as they moved around you
probably read stories about world war ii and the war with the japanese in which we won the battles of
coral sea and midway by virtue of having intercepted their their war plans for those two battles
there were a lot of successes through the years in intercepting communications
diplomatic communications military communications
and strategic communications that is the communications of leadersh leaders and
leadership and negotiations being carried on around the world the i'd say
the most important thing that happened during my tenure as the deputy director for operations
was that the agency realized that the world was going digital
and radio communications particularly long range radio communications
were moving to fiber and microwave and and cable and many other and satellites
and so we needed to modernize and i was fortunate enough to be the person who
uh guided that modernization so we brought 17 000 military people who had been
doing that job overseas at military bases in germany and japan and
and many other places some of which i had served at and we brought them home
and we put them into facilities here in the united states and we remoted
their operations to those facilities in the united states but then we added mission we added
satellite communications and all the other modes of communication so that
they had a much more enriched mission and they could do a much better job of producing intelligence from all of the
kinds of signals not just radio signals but those that came from
many other sources as well that was quite the quite the project and effort so one other topic i do want to cover
from your background is following that position of deputy director of operations he then became deputy
director of the nsa from 1994 to 1997 which i mentioned in your intro is the
highest ranking civilian role at the organization and essentially you acted as the group's chief operating officer i think this was
a pretty interesting time to be at the nsa from a historical perspective given the recent fall of the soviet union then
and a number of new threats that were brought about by the end of the cold war such as personal commuters you know cell
phones car based telephones and those became much more widespread could you talk a little bit more what some of
these new threats that were emerging were especially at the end of the cold war
well you know i had worked the soviet problem earlier i've been the head of the
organization that targeted the soviet union so when i became deputy director it was very clear
to me that although we weren't going to focus on soviet union anymore because it didn't exist anymore we were
going to have a lot of new threats around the world the one that bothered us the most was
terrorism osama bin laden had not emerged yet during my tenure there
but terrorism was increasing around the world afghanistan was certainly becoming a center of
terrorist training there were many other places like ethiopia of course palestine
and central africa and and so on that were spawning terrorist threats
and so that was that was a big thing because the communications of terrorists were
very ethereal very very difficult to find first of all they didn't announce i'm a
terrorist they you know and every one of them was named
the same thing in their communications so even if they used their real names a lot
of them were named muhammad so that was a terrific problem the languages were a
problem all kinds of languages were involved in the in the terrorism problem
and so it was a very difficult thing to to deal with the other emerging problems were the emerging nuclear threat in
other countries of the world we already had india pakistan france
uk and a few others that we don't mention because they won't they don't admit that they have nuclear weapons but
we had the emerging nuclear threats in north korea north korea the difficulties with iran
and so on and so that became a focus of a lot of attention again a very difficult problem because the
communications of the nuclear scientists and so on were cleverly hidden
and merged into the general communications of each of those nation
states and then there was the missile and and all of the high-tech
weapons programs that were going on around the world and again language problems problems getting into
uh the depths of their activities were very very difficult so
a lot of tough what we call hard targets iran was a very hard target north korea was a very hard target and
those hard targets nevertheless were the most important things that the u.s felt it had to deal with during those times
i left in 1997 you recall that osama bin laden became a
real problem in late 98 early 99 and
and of course in 2001. so fast forwarding today i do want to talk about some of the current challenges that we
face in security and bill you and i have talked about previously four key attack factors being supply chain attacks
ransomware apts advanced persistent threats and phishing would love for you to dive into those four key attack
factors in more detail and then also both ashley and colin from our class wanted to touch upon a few related
things in terms of ashley wanting to know a little bit more about some of the big problems that the industry is trying
to solve perhaps i think it might be helpful to put that in the context when describing the four key attack vectors
and colin's also very interested in touching upon consumer security and what we should be doing to safeguard
ourselves in our information yeah so by now every one of you should know what
a supply chain attack is we've been reading about them over the last month the most famous was
the solar winds attack which was just revealed i can tell you from
from open sources that is commercial sources that the the solar winds attack the
supply chain attack involving solarwind software began as early as february of 2020
and wasn't discovered until december of 2020 we still don't know how many
companies have been compromised the numbers range from
200 to 18 000 companies that were compromised
supply chain attacks are really insidious essentially the hackers or
attackers whichever name you want to give them attack the source
of software that's in current use by both commercial and
and government users and they wind their way through the
networks that serve those suppliers and they try to find their way into the
what's called the devops that is the development operations where code is
being written and and then they make changes to the suppliers own code the most
popular in the case of solarwinds change being to to essentially change the update
mechanism so that it provided updated copies of the software
to their customers that allowed entry into each customer's network and that's
a very insidious attack by the way it's not a new attack but it's a very insidious one and it's
it leads to the second vector that i talked about which is apts
are the advanced persistent threats because once you can get in then you can
begin leaving pieces of software in place in each of the targeted companies
or government agencies that allow you to repeatedly enter and remove files that you want to remove or
remove emails or or to even go so far as to be able to deal
at the keyboard level and capture keystrokes so you can capture more passwords you
can extend your your footprint within someone's networks until you get to all the critical pieces
their r d their software development all of the things that are important to
companies today the the third vector is ransomware and i i would assume that most of you have heard
a lot about it what you haven't probably realized is the most targeted
entities in the united states for ransomware up until recently were health facilities
hospitals and and health suppliers well wellness and health centers why
because that data is critical to them and they can hold it for ransom and collect pretty
pretty good numbers in their ransom but recently it's expanded a great deal to
where it now also includes things like government agencies and and
many other people who have critical very confidential information which they essentially encrypt
and hold for ransom and you can't decrypt it unless you pay them the ransom by the way
encryption is very effective these days if you don't have the keys the chances of you decrypting it or
almost nil i i'm quoted on the internet in a famous case that i was involved in
as saying that aes 128 that's the
that's the less effective form of the advanced encryption standard would
require all of the computers in the world
12 trillion times the age of the universe to break one message
that's pretty powerful encryption and so you don't break it by brute force
you have to be more clever than that and so ransomware is extraordinarily
effective and finally i i would assume that every one of you has received a phishing email
recently i receive about 10 to 15 a day they're called spear phishing in my case because my name is
associated with a lot of companies that are in the cyber security world
and also is associated with government agencies that have secrets and so they try every way in the world
to get me to click on links i just don't like click on any links but phishing is
the most popular way of finding your way into somebody's network and being able to exploit it
colin ashley anything um you wanted to ask or follow up on that yeah i have a quick question maybe there
are a bunch of like cyber security businesses now that do provide like anti-phishing software
but also provide kind of training for enterprises to to raise awareness around fishing
i'm curious if you have any thoughts on on those services and whether
that's enough or maybe it's a good starting point but you know and and i am very
colin i have very strong feelings you can't train your way out of the fishing problem it's it's a problem that
every time they do a test in the companies that don't have the training
they get about a 20 hit rate that is about 20 percent of the people will click on a
link they should know after the training about 15 of the people will click on a
link that they shouldn't have so we need technical solutions and i keep looking for companies
that have found ways to spot phishing emails using
high performance graphics analysis using artificial intelligence machine learning
and so on and i found a couple who were working on that but none have perfected it yet but i i just don't believe that
you can train your way out of the fishing problem that makes sense and i'll ask a really
specific question i'm curious if you're familiar with this company called fish me and they rebranded to coffee yes
i'm familiar with fish me yeah they were tied up in like some cyphus issue where the firm that

do you see that type of thing becoming like more of an issue with government getting more involved in companies in
the cyberspace for national security reasons yeah i don't believe fish fee was the
one that had russian lps i think it was another company which is now named
co-fence uh they they changed their name they used to be fish me and changed it to
co-friends yeah well anyway your question again
regarding yeah i guess it was around do you think that that's sort of an
isolated situation or what do you think about investment firms that you know have lps from from china and russia and
other you know nation states that might have complicated relationships with the us do you think

off well i i think we have to be concerned if there are foreign investors who have access
to trade secrets and other confidential information technical information in
companies that they are investing in so the the general idea is that we
in this country will limit foreign investment to
a financial role only no board seats and no no access to
non-disclosure information that's hard to carry out and it's it it's
you know it's not something that we practice as a country because we try to invest in
foreign companies in some cases but i personally stay out of
foreign investments either foreign investments into my companies are
investments in foreign companies in my case because i figured that that's not going to benefit either company
bill related to uh colin's question is a question from spencer that he previously flagged in terms of

i need to know whether the context is offense or defense i think it's defense

russia china iran
and then somewhere in there is israel and they might be
in the middle of that pact they might be at the top of that back it's hard to say
and as far as where the u.s is and offensive capabilities sometimes it's at
the top of that heap and sometimes it's not it depends on the kind of attack that
you're talking about on the defensive side our our problem is that our problem's twofold the first is
that the the offense only has to find one way and the defense has to find all of the ways
and so that makes for a very unequal equation it's like having uh
you know 50 simultaneous equations and and and somebody gives you a hand on one

u.s companies the great worry for me is how much success they enjoy in getting into
u.s critical infrastructure our financial systems our electrical
grid our transportation systems i mean they
they actually probably know every passenger on every airplane
because those aren't protected very well and and we could go through industry by
industry government organization by government organization and the answer would vary

if they determine that they need to get in they launch what are called
campaigns and the campaigns that iran for example launches against the
financial system because and north korea because that's their need
they need money they need hard currency and so that's what they go after the
russians want technology and the chinese want technology and so
they go after the aerospace companies and so on have you ever taken a look at the chinese stealth fighter
if you put a picture of the chinese stealth fighter on one side of the screen and the
us stealth fighter f35 on the other side of the screen they're virtually identical
and i once because of the winona thing that we started out with i became very good
friends with senator moynihan and my gift to him after the ceremony on
winona was a picture of the u.s fat boy which was our first
atomic bomb and the russian equivalent side by side
and each one had the u.s scientists standing next to it the other one had a russian scientist
standing next to it but the bombs were virtually identical
that's the importance of of these guys being able to hack into our technological base because they can
copy our technology and it doesn't cost them very much computers are cheap
did that answer your question spencer yeah that was very helpful thanks so much
so bill i do want to touch a little more upon modern day security threats and the changing threat landscape i love this

can you elaborate a bit more about how we need to catch up in our ability to defend and how should we think about

yeah we're running out of cyber security specialists in this country
at the present moment they're somewhere between 350 and 500 000
unfilled cyber security jobs in the united states and they're more than
more than a million unfilled in the world and that number is projected to go

crisis so we have to begin applying automation ai machine
learning and things that will relieve us of the need of having so many

are in existence i'm always a little worried about sore because if the enemy understands how it

automated systems off in a course that is not beneficial to us so we have to be
careful about that vulnerability assessment is really important i'm on the board of a company
that is called cyricon they've applied machine learning and ai
to the deep web and what they do is they mine the deep web for vulnerabilities that are being
discussed by hackers and and being exchanged in in various
irc or or conversations and so on and they do that in foreign languages as well
that is very very helpful because it leads them to be able to predict
which vulnerabilities by vulnerability class and name are going to be used in real attacks in

they should be patching their software how they should be locking down things in order to prevent attacks and so on so
in short you know we need to we need to smarten the system we need to do threat assessment we need to use
those threat assessments to guide responses and then we need to automate those responses
and on the topic of needing more security experts in government i do want to touch a bit upon government's role

be on the defense advance research projects agency advisory board
and during that time i discovered that that they were not spending any money on cyber security at all this is an
organization that's supposed to be helping us with technologies that are
quote over the horizon over the horizon not on the horizon
and i talked to the director of darpa and said uh this is shameful she said well it's
nsa they won't they won't let us i said well nsa is not in charge
so you should be putting money into it and you should be telling them where you're putting the money so that they

security and a lot of it was well spent particularly on critical infrastructure protection so the first job of
government is to spend money on research and to be able to bring advanced technologies i mean a lot of people are
skeptical about the government's role in technology but you know we all have devices
on us today we're using them right now that came from government programs like
vlsi turned into the high performance chips that we currently use in all of our
phones and computers and everything else that we have and our wearables as well so the first role is
technology and spending money because they can concentrate that money on
things that are not necessarily commercially viable at the moment
but could become viable for commercial applications down the road that's happening a lot more and more the second
area that they should be in involved in and they are now beginning to fix the problem
is information sharing the government is going to see in their role as
intelligence collectors and defenders of their own organizations and agencies
they're going to see attacks that are going to also occur in the commercial sector and in the critical
infrastructure sectors and they should be sharing that information you probably
noticed that ann neuberger from nsa recently became the national security
advisor for cyber security the new the new head of cyber security for the white
house is an ex-nsa person and so that these are people who are
highly trained in both offense and defense and they can help to guide
policy on information sharing or policy on research and development investment
and and many other areas as well so there's a there's a critical role for them and i think that
we're finally getting to the point where we're we are letting them play out that role
in a more credible way so bill we have about 15 minutes left now i do want to touch upon quantum computing as well as
crypto so on the quantum computing front what are the implications of quantum computing on security especially being
able to break rsa and what does that mean for guarding and encrypting data in the future and before answering that
question would love if he could first explain to the class a little bit more about rsa okay well i talked about aes
earlier and how unbreakable it is and that so you don't try and you don't try and attack the the symmetric key
cryptography that is out there because it's pretty damn strong but one of the things you can attack is
the key system the keying system and there are two ways that people distribute keys one is by physically
distributing them in advance that's msa's preferred method for many many years
and the second is by using a higher level mathematical exchange rsa
being one of the better known ways of doing key exchange in that very large
prime numbers are used to create a public key and a private key and the
public key is used to encrypt the the public key of the recipient is used
to encrypt the the key that you want to use in your aes system and they use their
private key then to decrypt it put it into their encryption device and be able
to software or hardware and be able to operate an encryption system so obviously if you could break
rsa or elliptic curve or diffie-hellman the three primary
mathematical techniques for exchanging keys then you would be able to get the
keys and be able to decrypt the communications well up until about 15 20 years ago
that was unthinkable because the prime numbers involved were like 20 48
bits long and almost indeterminable by any
conventional computer attack and then someone said well
what if we had this computer that could try everything all at once and then we just take the answers that
work and that's called a quantum computer and i happen to be on the board of the entanglement institute of and of
two other companies that are doing quantum research so i know a fair amount about quantum
computing i know it's very difficult we
we're not likely to see a quantum computer built in the next year
two years five years we don't know about 10 years and then in 15 years or 20 years it looks highly
likely so if you had that quantum computer you essentially could break every encryption system currently
in use on the internet tls uh ssl all of the ones that are used by
your banks and the uh fintech and so it's it's a
it's a golden ring or a brass ring whichever
uh one you want to identify it with but it's uh it's it's a big prize
and so a lot of money is going into quantum computing there's also a lot of money going into
quantum key exchange because it turns out that if we can't build a quantum
computer what we do know how to do is to exchange keys
using entanglement so that if the if the intended recipient
it has photons that are entangled with the ones that you send then he can get
the key but nobody else can because if they look at the keys then
they they no longer are entangled and and so it will fail chinese have been
successful in doing entanglement key exchange via satellite there are several
companies in the us that make fiber optic key exchange systems at the quantum level
but the big problem is quantum repeating because fiber
destroys the entanglement in about 40 kilometers so you need to solve that
problem so there's a lot of research going on in quantum computing quantum repeaters
quantum radars and quantum sensors and it's really exciting stuff
it's also very hard science i love it when i go to one of my companies
because there are 12 phds in that room with me and
it's it's a pretty exciting two days of exchange of information
some pretty big technical challenges we need to solve on the topic of crypto what are some of the implications of the

demand that the payment of the ransom be done in a cryptocurrency

there's no history of who bought what for you to recover your cryptocurrency yep some pretty sad

gives you an incredible insight into what the hacking community is doing and where

companies called run safe it's very interesting company essentially their approach is to to put
to take code let's say you've got an application to take that application code
and transform it uh into a random sequence
that it understands but if you look at it from the outside you can't understand
so the net result is that it's it's randomizing the code to observers but it
is not randomizing it to itself it's able to continue to execute its
role in its mission that's pretty exciting for example a lot of the u.s weapon systems are based on
very old code and the cost of upgrading that code to new operating systems
is extremely high but with their system you can actually obscure the the code
so that it still operates and and you don't have to upgrade other other
applications of their stuff is in the financial world and in the
what's called uh devsecops that is the development of secure applications in a automated way
so that the security portions particularly for open source portions of their code can be obscured
using their techniques another company that i'm excited about is
one that it's called seaport what it does is it essentially combines a com com a command
and control architecture with a security architecture
and it does two things as a result of that it allows you to have
much faster speeds in your encrypted communications and it also provides for
agile cryptography you can actually change the key for every packet that is transmitted and
received so you can be moving it around in terms of frequency
or channel or whatever at the same time you are moving it around cryptographically
changing it from aes 128 to aes 256 and and then changing the key
virtually every packet that's that's pretty difficult for people to work with it has one other exciting
component it can hide in plain sight it converts the let's say
you're running a vpn it converts the vpn from tcpip to udp
and so it looks like all the netflix traffic out there and it's pretty hard to find it if you can't
find the headers so it's it's also an exciting company there are others that that's just a
sample those are real startups there there are some that are a little more advanced that i also think

that a lot of the passwords and login credential information has been
